subject: Re: Ang: Re: [junit] DBC
msgSnippet: ... exactly!  And you don t have any run-time issues or complex build processes sitting around.  I tend to keep pre-condition checks in my code, but my tests
messageBody:
> From: steven.hale@...
>
> >Interesting to see that John Goodsen (private method thread) is using
> >Design By Contract in conjunction with unit testing and JUnit. Is anybody
> >else is doing this and how they are implementing DBC (iContract? JASS? or
> >merely at a documentation level?)
>
> Test-Driven Development drives a programmer towards DBC on a test-by-test
> basis. As a result, although I don't use DBC tools, I believe I'm doing DBC
>
> by simply writing the tests first. In a way, JUnit is my DBC tool.
>
> J. B. Rainsberger

exactly! And you don't have any run-time issues or complex build
processes sitting around. I tend to keep pre-condition checks in
my code, but my tests check for post conditions as well. Checking
for a failed post-condition at run-time in a production system
is not usually what you want anyways, since that means you are
in an undefined state if it fails anyways. Let the unit tests
find the post-condition failures for you *before* the code is
shipped.
